Award.AwardTitle: Principal bundles on local schemes and a duality for Hitchin systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports work on two projects in mathematics that have bearing on areas of physics. Its mathematical scope involves number theory, representation theory, and algebraic geometry and relates to what is now known as the Geometric Langlands Program. Robert Langlands in the 1960's proposed a program, which is a culmination of a sequence of theorems in number theory that began with the quadratic reciprocity theorem, proved by Gauss around 1800. Alexander Beilinson and Vladimir Drinfeld suggested a geometric version of the Langlands program, in which they brought the ideas of Langlands together with tools and ideas from other areas of mathematics and physics: algebraic geometry, sheaf theory, moduli spaces, integrable systems, and many others. Later, Anton Kapustin and Edward Witten in a breakthrough paper related the Geometric Langlands Program to supersymmetry and electro-magnetic duality. The central objects in the two projects are principal bundles for reductive algebraic groups; the PI plans to study certain questions about them in the context of the Geometric Langlands Program.

In the first project, partly in collaboration with Ivan Panin, the PI will apply techniques of the Geometric Langlands Program (namely, affine Grassmannians) to the local study of principal bundles. A principal bundle (that is, a torsor) for a reductive group scheme is not necessarily trivial in the Zariski topology. However, a conjecture of Grothendieck and Serre predicts that it is trivial if it is rationally trivial and the base is smooth. This conjecture is already proved in certain cases, but the PI aims to prove it in wider generality. The PI also plans to describe the necessary and sufficient conditions for extending a principal bundle over the fraction field to a neighborhood of a closed point. The second project, partly in collaboration with Dmitry Arinkin, is aimed at proving the quasi-classical version of the categorical Langlands correspondence. This is the equivalence between the derived category of the Hitchin integrable system for a reductive group and the derived category of the Hitchin system for the Langlands dual group. This should be viewed as an extension of the Fourier-Mukai transform for abelian varieties to singular degenerations of abelian varieties. There are strong indications that a proof of the duality for Hitchin systems will help with the proof of the original Geometric Langlands conjectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research project consists of two parts, both related to principal bundles in algebraic geometry. Principal bundles are ubiquitous in algebraic geometry, differential geometry, number theory, and even physics. For example, the standard model in physics is formulated in terms of principal bundles.

In 1950's Jean-Pierre Serre recognized the importance of principal bundles in algebraic geometry. In his 1958 seminal paper he gave first general definition of a principal bundle and formulated a certain deep conjecture. At the same time, a similar conjecture was formulated by Alexander Grothendieck. The conjecture was generalized and made more precise later; it became known as the conjecture of Grothendieck and Serre on principal bundles. Very roughly speaking, the conjecture predicts that, given a principal bundle over a punctured variety, there is at most one way to extend it to the puncture. 

The conjecture turned out to be very complicated. The "geometric" case of the conjecture was settled only a few years ago in a joint effort of many people, in particular, Manuel Ojanguren, Jean-Louis Colliot-Thelene, Ivan Panin, and the PI. However, the number-theoretic part of the conjecture remains open. In fact, very little was known about this case until the PI proved the conjecture in many number-theoretic cases. This is one of the major outcomes of this project. Another important outcome of the project is a certain simplification of the original proof of the conjecture in the geometric case.

The second part of the project is also related to principal bundles, but this time the bundles have additional structure called a Higgs field. This is, in a sense, a mathematical incarnation of the Higgs boson -- a recently discovered elementary particle. The PI studies the space parameterizing principal Higgs bundles over Riemann surfaces. This space was introduced by Nigel Hitchin in 1987. Hitchin has shown that the moduli space of Higgs bundles carries a structure of a so-called completely integrable system. This system is now called the Hitchin system, it has quickly become one of the central objects in mathematics.  In particular, its importance was recognized by Vladimir Drinfeld in his work on geometric Langlands duality. We need to say a few words about the latter. In the Langlands duality, one starts with a reductive algebraic group, for example, a group of invertible n x n matrices (denoted GL(n)) or a group of n x n matrices with determinant one (denoted SL(n)). It turns out that such groups come in pairs of the so-called Langlands dual groups. For example, GL(n) is self-dual (that is, equal to its Langlands dual) but the Langlands dual of SL(n) is the so-called projective linear group PGL(n) (this is the quotient of GL(n) by the center). One of the major goals of the PI (joint with Dima Arinkin) is to prove the Hitchin-Langlands duality, predicting that the Hitchin systems for Langlands dual groups are, in a sense, very similar (precisely, derived equivalent).


The Hitchin-Langlands duality for the group GL(n) is relatively well-developed, thanks to works of Dima Arinkin. The situation with other reductive groups is much more complicated. The duality is proved for the so-called smooth fibers by Ron Donagi and Toni Pantev but beyond that little is known. As a part of this project, The Pi and Dima Arinkin have constructed the so-called partial transform significantly extending the previous results. To this end, they developed a notion of a degenerate abelian scheme. Their results are applicable to any algebraically completely integrable system.

The broader impact of the project consists of a few components. The PI has given a few mini-courses at different levels (for high school students, freshmen, and sophomores in Dubna, Russia; for graduate students and postdocs in Lyon, France). The PI has given a few seminars for the undergraduate students planning to participate in the Putham mathematical competition; he hopes that these students will soon turn to mathematical research. He has also given talks in an undergraduate math seminar and in a math club. He is supervising research of both undergraduate and graduate students.
